awd_titl_txt: New Catalysts for Hydrocarbon Partial Oxidation
awd_abstract_narration:
The starting materials for the chemical industry are hydrocarbons derived from fossil sources (primarily natural gas and petroleum), which must be chemically converted into higher value materials. The chemical industry's energy consumption for these process is substantial and accounts for approximately 10% of total global energy use and greater than 5% of global carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions. Thus, while there are opportunities to dramatically increase the energy efficiency of large-scale chemical processes, there are also substantial scientific challenges to realizing this goal. In this project, T. Brent Gunnoe of the University of Virginia is developing a better understanding of how to perform selective and energy efficient chemical conversions that are essential to the goal of using natural gas and other fossil resources in a more environmentally benign manner. The project is a foundation for Professor Gunnoe to work with primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs) to develop a program to increase interest among students from diverse backgrounds in careers as scientists and engineers, especially in the energy arena. In this program, graduate students visit PUIs to deliver short courses based on their research, and undergraduate students participate in summer research internships in Professor Gunnoe's laboratory. This project impacts the chemical industry both in terms of sustainable innovation and workforce development. 

Professor Gunnoe is developing new catalysts based on rhodium (Rh), iridium (Ir) and copper (Cu) for the functionalization of carbon-hydrogen (C-H) bonds of hydrocarbons. A primary focus is how to combine transition metal mediated C-H activation and reductive functionalization of metal-hydrocarbyl ligands into catalytic cycles. Both transformations must be accessed under oxidizing conditions, which requires design of ligands to control the thermodynamics of metal-based redox chemistry. The outcome of these efforts is to access new catalysts that use air recyclable oxidants, thus enabling new catalytic processes for net aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons. The proposed chemistry builds on three primary developments, based on combined experimental and computational studies.  The development of ligand designs that optimize Rh- and Ir-mediated C-H activation in acidic solvents is investigated along with the development of ligand motifs that optimize reductive functionalization of RhIII-Me and IrIII-Me bonds to form Rh(I) and Ir(I) and MeX in acidic solvents (HX).  The investigators also examine the use of Cu(II) mediated arene functionalization by a non-free radical pathway. The project is a foundation for Professor Gunnoe to work with primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs) to develop a program to increase interest among students from diverse backgrounds in careers as scientists and engineers, especially in the energy arena. In this program, graduate students visit PUIs to deliver short courses based on their research, and undergraduate students participate in summer research internships in Professor Gunnoe's laboratory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Hydrocarbons, molecules that are comprised of only carbon and hydrogen, are the starting material for greater than 90% of the chemical industry's products including plastics, agricultural products and pharmaceuticals. Despite the maturity of this industry, many processes for the conversion of hydrocarbons to higher valuable materials consume substantial energy and generate chemical waste. For example, the chemical industry's energy consumption is ~42 EJ/year (including feedstocks), which is ~10% of total global energy use, and produces > 5% of global CO2 emissions. Thus, the design of more efficient processes for hydrocarbon conversions could have substantial positive benefit both economically as well as environmentally while conserving precious carbon-based fossil resources.

 

One strategy to convert hydrocarbons into higher value and useful materials is to use a catalyst. For the conversion of hydrocarbons, catalysts serve to break carbon-hydrogen (C-H) bonds and to make new bonds that generate desired new chemicals. Current catalytic methods for hydrocarbon functionalization typically involve multi-step and energy intensive processes, and the increasing global demand for fossil resources in combination with mounting pressure to reduce environmental impact render the development of more efficient methods for hydrocarbon processing a critical need.  New molecular catalysts offer the opportunity to achieve reactions that functionalize hydrocarbons with high selectivity and low waste production and energy consumption. But, to realize these opportunities improved understanding of how to design new molecular catalysts to control the energetics of key reactions in overall processes is critically important. 

 

This project was focused on new understanding of how to design the catalyst active site (that is, the site that is responsible for bond breaking and bond formation) to optimize for desired chemical conversions of hydrocarbons. Specifically, we pursued two objectives: 

 

Objective 1. Development of catalytic hydrocarbon oxidation based on complexes of rhodium and iridium with ligands designed to control redox reactivity. 

 

Objective 2. Develop catalytic hydrocarbon oxidation using copper(II) catalyst precursors including elucidation of mechanistic details. 

 

The intellectual merit of Objective 1 is derived from an enhanced understanding of how to design ligands, which are organic molecules chemically bonded to the active catalyst stie, to facilitate key chemical reactions in overall catalytically processes for hydrocarbon functionalization. Our efforts were focused on a class of ligand that we have named "capping arene" ligands. These ligands have a modular structure that allows an arene group to be placed at different distances from the transition metal center (rhodium, iridium), and the metal/arene distance was shown to impact the rate and yields of reductive elimination reactions, which are chemical transformations that are product forming steps in catalytic reactions. For Objective 2, we demonstrated that earth abundant copper(II) carboxylate complexes can mediate arene functionalization reactions. Importantly, it was shown that these reactions likely involve intermediates with copper aryl bonds, which offers opportunities for unique and selective functionalization reactions. The arenes studied (benzene and toluene) are abundant from fossil resources. The research accomplished in this project sets the stage for continued efforts to develop new catalytic processes for hydrocarbon functionalization.

 

This award supported the research of four graduate (Ph.D.) students and two undergraduate students. These students developed expertise in an array of experimental skills, received extensive safety training, and participated in programs to enhance their professional development. Two of the graduate students have completed their Ph.D. and are now employed by a companies in the chemical and pharmaceutical industries. Two graduate students remain in our Ph.D. program and are making progress toward completion of their degree. The undergraduate students completed their degrees and are pursuing professional degrees. The students disseminated the results of their research through presentations at scientific conferences, in their theses and through peer reviewed publications.  

 

Graduate researchers supported by this project participated in an outreach program with Heritage University (HU). HU is an independent, non-profit, non-denominational, liberal arts university centrally located on the Yakama Indian Reservation in rural, agricultural eastern Washington state. HU is the only four-year liberal arts university in the United States located on a federally recognized American Indian Reservation and is designated as both a Native American serving, non-tribal institution and a Hispanic Serving Institution. The graduate students, working with faculty mentors, developed and implemented a teaching module at HU with a focus on environmental analysis of interest to the HU students and local population. Further, during the two-day visit to HU, graduate students interacted significantly with HU undergraduate students, and discussed research opportunities and graduate programs with them.
